tit.cmt: Senshafuda削除して次の項で説明。

sen.j: 千社札（せんしゃふだ、せんじゃふだ）とは、神社や仏閣に参拝をした記念として貼る、自分の名前入りの札のこと。
sen.e: Senjafuda is a card or slip stuck to shrines and temples on which visitor's name is printed as a memorial of the visit.
Senjafuda is a card or slip stuck to shrines and temples on which visitor's name is printed as a memorial of the visit.
Senjafuda (also referred to as Senshafuda) is a card or slip stuck to shrines and temples on which visitor's name is printed as a memorial of the visit.
sen.cmt: Senshafuda を括弧書きで入れました。

sen.j: 元来は銅板で作られていたが、江戸時代以降は紙が用いられることが多い。
sen.e: Originally, it was a strip made of copper, however, in and after Edo period, usually paper was used.
Originally, it was a strip made of copper, however, during and after the Edo period, paper was usually used.

sen.j: 更に、ごく最近ではシール状になっているものも多く、これらはゲームセンター等に設置されている専用の作成機で、名前等を入力した上で作成することが出来る。
sen.e: Further, sticker type is often used most recently and this is made by special machines placed at penny arcade and so on with which one can input his name, etc. on it and make a card.
Recently sticker types are most often used and this is made with special vending machines where one can input his name and make a card.

sen.j: また、手軽に作成できるようになり、本来の用途とは外れた様々な用途に使用されることが増えてきている。
sen.e: As it becomes easy to make this senjafuda, people use it in many ways out of the original purpose.
As it has become easy to make senjafuda, people use them in many ways other than for the original purpose.

sen.j: 千社札には、幅が一寸六分 (数)（58ミリメートル）、高さが四寸八分（173ミリメートル）の一丁札が用いられる。
sen.e: For senjafuda, a strip called iccho-fuda (a 1 cho-sized card) of 58mm in width and 173mm in length is used.

sen.j: この中に描いた子持ち枠と呼ばれる枠の中に文字などを記入する。
sen.e: A frame called komochi-waku (an inner frame where characters are printed in) is printed on the card and inside of it, characters such as name and so on are described.

sen.e: Meanwhile, the komochi-waku was stipulated in 1887 to make in width 48mm by length 144mm as the outside size.

sen.j: 通常、神社や仏閣に奉納するための札は墨による単色刷りだが、交換や蒐集、鑑賞などの目的のために、多色刷りされた色札が作成されることもある。
sen.e: Normally, senjafuda dedicated to shrines and temples are claro obscuro of India ink, however, multiple color printed 'irofuda (literally, colored card)' are often made for exchange, collection and appreciation.

sen.j: 愛好家同士で納札交換会を催して楽しむこともある。
sen.e: Fanciers sometimes hold and enjoy a gathering of votive cards exchanges.

sen.j: また京都の花街などでは名刺の代わりに図柄入りの千社札もあり花名刺とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: In 'Hanamachi (or 'Kagai', geisha districts)' in Kyoto, they use patterned senjafuda instead of business card which is called 'Hanameishi (literally, flower business card.)

sen.j: 文字には主に江戸文字が用いられ、錦絵と同じ江戸版画によって印刷される。
sen.e: The letters are mainly in characters designed in Edo era, and senjafuda is printed in the same way as 'Edo-hanga', a wood block prints produced in and around Edo era which is used to print nishiki-e (a color woodblock print.)

sen.j: 奉納の際には通常目立つところに貼るが、隠し貼りといって風雨に晒されず目立たないところに貼ることもある。
sen.e: Usually, senjafuda is stuck to conspicuous place of the buildings of shrines or temples when dedicated, however, it is sometimes stuck to by-place not to exposed to rain and wind which is called 'kakuhsi-bari (secret pasting.)'

sen.e: When senjafuda dedicated to shrines and temples were stuck to ceilings and walls and long time has passed, the vacant part of the paper became eroded and gone out, and only printed or written part by India ink or so are left.

sen.e: Recently, easily-made sticker type senjafuda is increased and used other than religious purposes such as a business card and some kind of amulet stuck to 'bachi' (drumsticks) of a drum master to stir himself when he performs.
